title: ISic000781. Funerary inscription of Aurelius Samohil

4ne que fatum conplebit XII (vac.1) kal(endas) Â· Novebr-
5es diae Veneris luna octaba Mero-
6baudes iterum et Satornino con-

2EGOAURELIUS    SAMOHILCONPARABI
3MEMORIAMMIETOXSORISMAEELASIEERI
4NEQUEFATUMCONPLEBITXII  KALÂ·NOVEBR
5ESDIAEVENERISLUNAOCTABAMERO
6BAUDESITERUMETSATORNINOCON
7SULIBUSQUAEVIXITANNOSXXIII  CUM
8PACE  ADIUROVOSPERVICTORIASQUIIN
9PERANTITEMADIUROVOSPERHONOR
10ESPATRIARCARUMITEMADIUROVOS

l.3 reg., orig. mi | reg., orig. oxsoris | reg., orig. maee | l.5 reg., orig. diae | l.11 reg., orig. ligem | l.14 p

Facsimile Images

Apparatus criticus

  • Text from autopsy

English translation

Jonathan Prag

Peace upon Israel. Amen, amen, peace. Samuel. I, Aurelius Samohil (=Samuel), bought the memorial for myself and my wife Lassia Irene, who completed her allotted span on the 12th day before the Kalends of November (21 October), the day of Venus (Friday), in the eighth moon (Jewish month of Heshwan), when Merobaudes for the second time and Saturninus were consuls; she lived for 23 years with peace. I adjure you by the victories (of those) who rule, likewise I adjure you by the honours of the patriarchs, likewise I adjure you by the law which the lord gave the Jews: let no-one open the memorial and put the body of someone else on top of our bones; but if anyone does open it, let them give ten pounds of silver to the treasury.

Italian translation

Serena Agodi

Pace su Israele. Amen, amen pace. Samuel. Io, Aurelius Samohil (=Samuel), acquistai una tomba per me e mia moglie Lassia Irene, che completÃ² il suo percorso assegnato dal Fato dodici giorni prima delle calende di novembre (=21 ottobre), giorno di Venere (=venerdÃ¬), nell'ottava luna (nel mese ebraico di Heshwan), consoli Merobaudes per la seconda volta e Saturnino (=383 d.C.); visse ventitre anni con pace. Vi scongiuro per le vittorie di coloro che governano, parimenti vi scongiuro per gli onori dei patriarchi, parimenti vi scongiuro per la legge che il signore ha dato agli ebrei: nessuno apra la tomba e metta il corpo di qualcun altro sopra le nostre ossa; ma se qualcuno dovesse aprirlo, possa egli dare al fisco il peso di dieci libbre di argento.

commentary

This is the only Latin (and Hebrew) inscription from the Jewish community in Sicily, and it is the longest Latin text from the Jewish diaspora in this period; it also provides the earliest datable evidence for the Jewish community in Catania. The Latin is marked by phonological and syntactical errors (e.g. mi(mihi) et osxoris (uxori)), and it is likely that Latin was chosen not because it was familiar but because it was the high status language of public documents - the inscription aims to present Aurelius as a member of the local Ã©lite. The Hebrew is very formulaic and does not prove good knowledge of the language. Lassia is a rare name found otherwise in Campania in the early Imperial period. Threats of this sort against damage to the tomb are common in pagan and Christian inscriptions also. It is notable that Aurelius appeals equally to Roman, Jewish, and divine authority for protection.

  • Manganaro 1993 564 fig.7 https://biblio.inscriptiones.org/epig10001827
  • Noy 1993 no.145 https://biblio.inscriptiones.org/epig10000166
  • GrÃ¼ll 2000 https://biblio.inscriptiones.org/epig10001932
  • Manganaro 2004-2005 360-362 fig.2 https://biblio.inscriptiones.org/epig10003134
  • Giuffrida 2020 75-80 https://biblio.inscriptiones.org/epig10002323
